title-group.article-title: Response to Reactions to Major Contribution
title-group.subtitle: Multicultural Clinical Supervision and Benchmarks

article-meta.aff: 1Pepperdine University, West Los Angeles, CA, USA

author-notes.corresp: Carol A. Falender, PhD, Graduate School of Education and Psychology, Pepperdine University, West Los Angeles, 1158 26th Street, #189, Santa Monica, CA 90403, USA Email: cfalende@pepperdine.edu

permissions.copyright-holder: Division of Counseling Psychology of the American Psychological Association

abstract.p: The authors responded to the commentaries on the Major Contribution, “Multicultural Clinical Supervision and Benchmarks: Empirical Support Informing Practice and Supervisor Training.” The commentaries provided a structure of consensus, critical questions, and requests for additional elaboration. The commentators advocated for the urgent need to move forward translating clinical supervision, a distinct professional competency, directly into training and practice in the United States. They also agreed on the essential multicultural framework and the imperative for empirical research to provide validation for the Competency Benchmarks as a developmental training schema. The authors also provided responses with regard to future directions for supervision and training parameters.

sec.title: Response to Reactions to The Counseling Psychologist Major Contribution: Multicultural Clinical Supervision and Benchmarks: Empirical Support Informing Supervision Practice and Supervisor Training
sec.p: We thank the discussants and applaud their thoughtful integration of the implications and data from the Major Contribution (MC) and the panoply of ideas for further research and practice. The responses expanded the discourse in a range of intriguing ways. Most important is the consensus concerning the importance of the attitudinal shift within psychology in the United States to treat clinical supervision as a distinct professional competency that requires specific standards and guidelines and that the MC will serve as a stimulus to galvanize change. Many of the comments follow directly from the lag throughout multiple levels of education and training of professional psychologists in the United States to affirm (a) that clinical supervision competence requires separate knowledge, skills, and attitudes/values and (b) that the complexity of supervision with its compound frames of reference and multicultural worldviews [client(s), therapist/supervisee, and supervisor] warrants both empirical and theoretical exploration. The commentaries supported our initial effort toward identifying effective supervisory practices, using multicultural, international, and diverse samples, providing preliminary evidence with regard to the Competency Benchmarks (Fouad et al., 2009).

The commentators—Westefeld and Rasmussen (2013), Foo Kune and Rodolfa (2013), and Grus (2013)—identified several pivotal issues: (a) All commentators viewed the individual articles as a significant step in delineating common factors, essential components of effective supervision, or specific competencies requisite for effective supervision. (b) All commentators urged that the field enhance the valence of clinical supervision in psychology by infusing supervision comprehensively as a distinct competency into doctoral curriculum, clinical training, and professional practice in the United States. (c) Foo Kune and Rodolfa (2013) questioned whether the Benchmarks are too complicated to be widely adopted and should be reduced to a maximum of six clusters. (d) All commentators questioned whether the developmental framework on which the Benchmarks are built is sufficiently robust to bear the scrutiny of empirical study and urged that such study must be timely, that is, designed to assess supervisee development and ultimately client outcomes. Failure to produce empirical evidence for the Benchmarks will fuel the status quo and, from their and our perspectives, negatively affect future generations of psychologists.

Foo Kune and Rodolfa (2013) itemized aspects of the data from the MC that correspond to the theoretical basis for Bordin’s (1983) supervisory working alliance model. We suggest, however, that Bordin’s extrapolation from the psychotherapy alliance did not add the most salient distinction between therapy and supervision—the power differential and the resultant evaluation and gatekeeping required of the supervisor to ensure the safety of the client and the integrity of the profession. It will be essential for supervisors to be mindful of the power differential as a major factor affecting supervision and the supervisory relationship, which is further confounded by multicultural variables as well as privilege and oppression factors (Yabusaki, 2010).

The commentators raised concerns about the definition of supervision, a controversial topic and a bellwether of the evolution of definitions that reflect the changing tides of supervision theory and pedagogy. Definitions of supervision have thus far focused on the relationship, power differentials, translation to facilitate empirical support (e.g., Milne, Aylott, Fitzpatrick, & Ellis, 2008), evidence-based components, multicultural issues, and a critical tension between collaboration and hierarchy (Bernard & Goodyear, 2009; Falender & Shafranske, 2004). A consensual definition will be an important requisite for empirical study of clinical supervision.

sec.title: The Competency Benchmarks and Beyond
sec.p: To address these questions and issues, we digress briefly. Consider that in the Benchmarks document (Fouad et al., 2009), supervision is mentioned/referenced 13 times outside of the specific Supervision and Teaching competency areas and is included in every foundational competency except Interdisciplinary Systems. As Foo Kune and Rodolfa (2013) suggested, part of the complexity of implementing the Benchmarks in supervision is the overlapping compulsory skill sets, such that supervision not only has its own set of competencies but also involves multiple constellations of competencies. For example, the Essential Foundational and Functional competencies of Reflective Practice/Self-Assessment/Self-Care, Relationships, Individual/Cultural Diversity, Ethical, Legal Standards and Policy, Interventions, and Assessment require the supervisor and supervisee to be highly fluent in the Benchmarks to both track effectively and monitor multiple competencies simultaneously.

For this level of integration, at least two things need to occur. First, the Benchmarks must be firmly embedded in all Counseling, Clinical, and School Psychology graduate training programs in both didactic and fieldwork components, with ongoing self-monitoring strategically linked to the specific competencies, essential components, and behavioral indicators. Second, the professional and regulating bodies in the United States need to institutionalize clinical supervision competencies. From our perspective, doing both is obligatory. It is noteworthy that other professions and disciplines in the United States (e.g., American Counseling Association) (Borders et al., 1991; National Association of Social Workers, 1996) and abroad (e.g., British Association for Counselling, 1988) developed guidelines or competency statements for supervision decades ago. As professional psychology across the anglophile world has advanced guidelines and competencies for clinical supervision (e.g., Australian Capital Territory Psychologists Board, 2009; Australian Psychological Society, 2003; British Psychological Society, 2003, 2006; Canadian Psychological Association [CPA], 2009; New Zealand Psychologists Board, 2009, 2010a, 2010b), psychology in the United States is endeavoring to catch up. Concurrent with the Major Contribution going to press, Campbell and colleagues (2012) released A Practical Guidebook for the Competency Benchmarks that delineates the use of the Competency Benchmarks Evaluation System (CBES) and implementation of the Competency Assessment Toolkit (Kaslow et al., 2009). Evaluation forms are provided for the three developmental levels articulated in the Benchmarks (readiness for practicum, internship, and entry to practice, respectively) plus an evaluation form for interpersonal and relationship competencies. Campbell et al. (2012) and Kaslow et al. (2009) will be invaluable resources for academic training programs, pre-doctoral internships, and post-doctoral agencies, as well as for the broader profession, as the field transforms forward with a competency-based approach to the profession.

Foo Kune and Rodolfa’s (2013) reflection on the various frameworks developed by the Association of State and Provincial Psychology Boards (ASPPB), the American Psychological Association (APA), and the Competencies Conference (e.g., Fouad et al., 2009) raises a pivotal issue of the interface between regulatory bodies that address practitioners’ competence to protect the public and the training institutions that ensure the competence standards are achieved during the training trajectory. In essence, the task is to determine that which will be regulated by statutes (state licensure laws, ethical standards, and regulations) and that which will be governed by professional entities (e.g., APA, CPA) via accreditation, practice guidelines, and ethical standards. One question is whether it is possible to have one document that meets the needs/criteria for both. On a cautionary note, if supervision is to be combined as a competency with Interventions and Consultation as suggested by the ASPPB Practice Analysis (ASPPB, 2010) or simply contained under a rubric such as Education (Revised Benchmarks Clusters and Core Competencies; APA, 2012), we fear that the recognition and institutionalization of clinical supervision as a distinct professional practice will be diminished, if not lost. Similarly, if categories are combined and condensed, should Professionalism, an essential competency for supervisees, be combined with Ethics as recommended in the Practice Analysis (ASPPB, 2010). By doing so, are we overshadowing professionalism and devaluing its distinct importance as a major competency to be achieved in the training trajectory? This question is especially of concern, as early unprofessional behavior in other helping professional training programs (e.g., medical school) has been significantly associated with later disciplinary actions by state licensing boards (Papadakis et al., 2005). Furthermore, we should be mindful of the worrisome recent reports of faculty supervisor behavior in medical school training distinctly lacking in professionalism, or even respectful behavior (Fried, Vermillion, Parker, & Uijtdehaage, 2012), and the growing data that supervisees often experience harmful supervision, connoting a distinct lack of professionalism among training staff (Ellis et al., 2010; Ellis et al., 2009) who serve as major role models for developing psychologists.

The Benchmarks were intended to be a developmental training roadmap rather than a regulatory one, however, so that settings including doctoral programs, practicum, and internship settings would identify relevant portions for their particular practice area(s) and that the entire document would not be relevant for each site. In line with Rodolfa et al.’s (2005) competency cube, the Benchmarks could be transformed spatially to a geometric or multi-dimensional figure to address redundancy, reducing complexity. We share Foo Kune and Rodolfa’s (2013) concerns that the Benchmarks not be so reduced as to lose the behavioral indicators, essential tools with promise for enhancing the usefulness and reliability of monitoring supervisee development and providing supervisor feedback. Grus’s (2013) thoughtful analysis of the history of competencies in supervision provides essential perspective for future directions.

To move into the competencies culture, with clinical supervision acknowledged as a distinct professional practice for psychologists, it is time for both regulations and guidelines for supervisory practice in the United States. A confluence of groups is addressing these issues; CPA, APA Board of Educational Affairs (BEA), and ASPPB all have had or are in the process of developing more specific guidelines for supervisory practice. The BEA charge to the Supervision Guidelines Task Force was to develop education and training guidelines for best practices in (a) the provision of supervision and (b) the teaching of a competency-based approach to supervision and to include consideration of supervision at various stages of trainee development (BEA, March 2012 minutes). The BEA Task Force coordinated their efforts with those concurrently under way by the Supervision Competencies Task Force convened by the ASPPB to develop a resource document for state and provincial boards of psychology as they develop their own regulations with regard to supervision and requirements for licensure as a psychologist (Schaffer, 2011). The work of these two task forces will no doubt have a profound effect on professional psychology in the next decade, especially for clinical supervision training and practice and the movement to competencies.

sec.title: Future of Training in Clinical Supervision
sec.p:
We appreciate Westefeld and Rasmussen’s (2013) request for more specific strategies to integrate supervision into curricula and training. A significant area of future exploration is the development of empirically supported models to enhance effective supervisor training. Particularly, all the commentaries emphasized the importance of enhancing supervision competency in the academic pipeline. Given that supervision is mentioned only once in the current standards, Westefeld and Rasmussen (2013) suggested changes to the APA Committee on Accreditation Standards, strengthening the requirements or suggested competencies for supervisees as they transition to serving as clinical supervisors:
Domain B., 4. “In achieving its objectives, the program requires that all interns demonstrate an intermediate to advanced level of professional psychological skills, abilities, proficiencies, competencies, and knowledge in the areas of: (b) Theories and/or methods of consultation, evaluation, and supervision.” (Retrieved from http://www.apa.org/ed/accreditation/about/policies/interns.aspx)

This analysis of standards prompts professional psychologists to question (a) how a clinician is prepared to become a clinical supervisor, (b) at what point an individual is ready to become a supervisor, (c) what the requisite level of clinical competence is, and (d) how professional psychologists assess the readiness of trainees to engage in the transition to becoming a supervisor, or (e) should it simply occur at a given moment in the training trajectory—either at the point of licensure or several years thereafter? An expectation for supervisors at the point of readiness for independent practice requires that the supervisor “articulates a philosophy or model of supervision and reflects on how this model is applied in practice, including integrated contextual, legal, and ethical perspectives” (Benchmarks, Supervision, A. Readiness for Independent Practice; Fouad et al., 2009, p. S21). It would be important to assess how many supervisors articulate such a model in their practice, and if so, if it is comprehensive across all the areas of the Benchmarks (e.g., Individual and Cultural Diversity, Ethical, Legal Standards and Policy). A developing trend is the reconceptualization of multiple psychotherapy-based models of supervision into competency-based structures to ensure adequate attention to the abundant complexities of supervision that differ from psychotherapy (Farber & Kaslow, 2010; Watkins, 2012). The preliminary framework of supervisor competencies in Table 1 was a product of the 2002 Competencies Conference (Falender et al., 2004, p. 778).

tr.td: 1. Coursework in supervision including knowledge and skill areas listed
2. Has received supervision of supervision including some form of observation (videotape or audiotape) with critical feedback
1. Successful completion of course on supervision
2. Verification of previous supervision of supervision documenting readiness to supervise independently
3. Evidence of direct observation (e.g., audiotape or videotape)
4. Documentation of supervisory experience reflecting diversity
6. Self-assessment and awareness of need for consultation when necessary
7. Assessment of supervision outcomes—both individual and group

sec.p: We proffer that counseling, school, and clinical psychology doctoral programs should require self-contained coursework in supervision as supervisees desire (Crook-Lyon, Presnell, Silva, Suyama, & Stickney, 2011) rather than being superseded or combined with internship preparation, consultation, professional development, or professional roles. Ideally, applied programs in psychology will develop two to three courses: One will occur at the onset of clinical training to prepare the supervisee to be effective in that role and lay the groundwork of specific tenets of supervision structure, expectations, theory, research, skills, and process (Falender & Shafranske, 2012). The second course would address the transition from supervisee to supervisor and would occur after a minimum of two practicum experiences. In that course, the supervisee would be introduced to the perspective of supervisor, a significant cognitive shift, and would learn knowledge, skills, and attitudes to ensure effective supervision practice. Another option for the second course is a formal, structured, applied practicum in supervision to emphasize such training. Models include supervisees conducting peer supervision on less advanced cohorts or role-playing supervision with peers and an experienced supervisor during practicum supervision. In the third course, supervisees will have an opportunity to receive supervision of supervision—while they are supervising a less experienced counselor or therapist. Psychologists can work within academic programs to create opportunities for advanced students to supervise master’s students, receive supervision-of-supervision in an individual or group format, and receive academic credit for such work, thereby having such work reflected on their transcript. Each of these courses could be of shorter duration than a full term.

Singularly little attention has been devoted to the process of the development of the supervisor, most effective training paradigms, and assessment of the process. The most common training format is a 1- or 2-day workshop focused on skills and knowledge with some attention to attitudes. However, there has been inadequate formal assessment of efficacy, pre- and post-functioning of the effect of workshops on participants’ behavior and client outcome, although participant satisfaction with continuing education is high (Neimeyer, Taylor, & Wear, 2009). The lack of these data notwithstanding, there would be little argument that such training alone would be considered sufficient to qualify someone to be a therapist—yet this is the practice for clinical supervisors. Thus, assessment of the effect of various protocols of supervision training is an essential next step to identify effective multiculturally relevant training strategies.

It will also be important to train and supervise individuals post-graduate school who are performing supervision without prior formal training. In general, protocols include both short and extended courses ideally with a built-in evaluative component whether it be a test of knowledge or a follow-up video review. There should be movement toward formal assessment of the effect of supervision on client outcomes and supervisee development on benchmarks. Training would be geared to generally instilling the notion that clinical supervision is a protective factor and a component of lifelong learning and development as strongly urged by Westefeld and Rasmussen (2013) and practiced in other countries (e.g., New Zealand Psychologists Board, 2010b). It is likely that until supervisors generally value and adopt lifelong learning paradigms, we will be stymied in our progress to a culture of competence.

The biggest shift will need to be in the attitudes/values concerning clinical supervision—its existence as a distinct professional competency. Supervisors must engage in transformational leadership strategies to achieve this outcome (Kaslow, Falender, & Grus, 2012). What will follow are investigations of effective multiculturally competent supervision practices, how effective supervision is learned and taught, and how supervision outcomes can be effectively assessed. In addition, recognition will propel understanding that supervision is collaborative, providing supervisors the motivation to grow and learn from and with their supervisees in the process. Finally, we hope that more researchers will become inspired to investigate clinical supervision, therapist training and development, and competencies thereof.

fn.p: The authors received no financial support for the research, authorship, and/or publication of this article.

bio.title: Bios
bio.p: Carol A. Falender is Adjunct Professor, Pepperdine Graduate School of Education and Psychology, Los Angeles, and Clinical Professor, Department of Psychology, University of California, Los Angeles. A Fellow of APA (Division 37), she is co-chair of the Society of Counseling Psychology’s (Division 17) Section for Supervision and Training. Her areas of teaching and scholarship include competency-based clinical supervision, supervisor training, supervisor competence, and international supervision ethics.

Michael V. Ellis, PhD, is a professor and Director of the Division of Counseling Psychology, in the Department of Educational and Counseling Psychology at the University at Albany, SUNY. He is a Fellow of APA (Division 17), an Approved Clinical Supervisor, and recipient of the Supervision and Training Section’s 2010 Outstanding Professional Achievement Award. His teaching and research interests include multicultural clinical supervision, supervisor training, clinical judgment, and research methodology, psychometrics, and statistics. He also maintains a private practice.

Theodore R. Burnes, PhD, is an associate professor and member of the Multicultural-Community Psychology emphasis at the California School of Professional Psychology at Alliant International University in Los Angeles. He is the past chair of the Society of Counseling Psychology’s (Division 17) Section for Supervision and Training and an approved clinical supervisor. His teaching and research interests include mental health and wellness for LGBTQI people, multicultural clinical supervision, training in professional psychology, qualitative research methodologies, sexuality and sexual practice, and resilience-based trauma therapy. He also maintains a private practice.
